awd_titl_txt: ACES: A scholarship program for atmospheric and computer science exploratory scholars
awd_abstract_narration:
ACES: A Scholarship Program for Atmospheric and Computer Science Exploratory Scholars will provide scholarship and academic support for thirty four undergraduate students majoring in the Atmospheric and Computer Sciences (A&CS) over five years while enrolled at University of North Carolina at Asheville (UNCA).  ACES will add to the knowledge of the effectiveness of community-based A&CS undergraduate learning experiences by building cohorts for A&CS students to establish support groups designed to encourage early academic success, monitoring student progress through a student management team, offering help to struggling students by providing peer tutors to assist in low- and mid-level A&CS science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) courses, enlisting peer and faculty mentors to help resolve issues inside and outside the classroom, and providing opportunities for students to engage in activities in three discipline areas (research, teaching, and operations) to expand the types of A&CS STEM career options under consideration by undergraduates.

ACES objectives are to (1) motivate high school and transfer students demonstrating both strong academic potential and financial need to seriously consider majors in the atmospheric or computer sciences, (2) pique and maintain the interest of students while they are enrolled in the challenging curriculum of their major as undergraduates, particularly during their first and second years, when their curriculum is focused primarily on completing the liberal arts general education requirements, (3) expose students to a variety of discipline areas and career paths within the major, (4) prepare students for their chosen career path, and (5) make ACES sustainable beyond the initial support provided by the NSF.  Student data (e.g. grade point averages, comprehensive examination scores, etc.) and surveys will be used to assess the effectiveness of program components and evaluate the overall success of the project.  The results will be shared with other departments within the institution to serve as a model for other programs.  Dissemination to the broader STEM community will occur through disciplinary conference presentations and papers published in educational journals that specifically target the atmospheric and computer sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Lessons Learned

The following discussion provides details of the main points presented on the ACES final project report poster (see ‘aces_final_report_poster_fnl’).


The major project goal having the greatest mystery was [1] attracting highly qualified students. Today’s pre-college students apply to an astonishing number of colleges/ universities (eight, on average) and moving our university to the top of their preferred list is most likely if the student makes a campus visit. Gauging the commitment of the pre-college student’s application was particularly difficult to assess, but the low number of acceptances of ACES scholarship offers suggests a large number of students applying to our programs were noncommittal to our university. Even after adding an additional ‘hoop’ to the ACES application procedure (simple online survey), we found it failed to sift out the non-serious applicant. Declined scholarship offers also suggested the FAFSA expected family contribution may cast too large a burden on families so that the modest $6000 annual ACES scholarship offer was insufficient to persuade students to attend UNCA. In support of this notion, we have several current ACES Scholars who work part-time jobs while also attending classes, even after qualifying for the full annual scholarship amount ($6000). Unfortunately, our plans for making more personal communications with prospective scholarship students in Spring 2020 were made impossible when the campus was closed and remote learning became the mode of delivering the curriculum.


The major goal having the greatest challenge was [4] preparing students for careers in or related to their major. The fields of atmospheric science and computer science have rapidly evolving job openings that respond to advances in technology. The challenge, for faculty in a fixed (and often isolated) perspective, is to anticipate the evolution of job types within these fields, jobs that may not have existed when the student was in their first year. For this reason, communication with graduates in these fields was essential so we could get their perspective on emerging job types and, hopefully, communicate with our current students the knowledge and skills required to meet the needs of the expanding breadth of private and public sector jobs.


Major goals having the greatest success were [2] the retention of students and [3] the provision of a well-rounded education. Much was implemented at UNCA to meet the needs of these goals and recent trends of students staying in their major might suggest these measures were successful. Most of the efforts listed on the poster under major goal [2] did not exist before initiation of the ACES Project and most will continue at UNCA upon project completion. Feedback from recent surveys of ‘The Cloud’ living learning community suggest the sense of belonging experienced by ATMS and CSCI students has improved significantly at UNCA and is consistent with a decreased number of students leaving the ATMS or CSCI major. In addition to helping with retention, the outreach and mentoring activities undertaken in support of a [3] well-rounded education also applied to building a sense of community and retention improvement.
